render.tex: %text The differential equation for \[ \qquad y = \fx \] where $A$ and $B$ are arbitrary constants is \[ \qquad \frac{d^2y}{dx^2} + \alpha^2 y = 0 \] %

reason.tex:
%text We need to find the \underline\text{general} differential equation which when solved gives the \underline\text{specific} solution $y = \fx$ Hence, we need to get rid off $A$ and $B$ % \begin{align}
y &= \fx \\ \therefore \dydx &= \dfx \\ \text{and } \frac{d^2y}{dx^2} &= -\alpha^2 A \cos\alpha x - \alpha^2 B\sin\alpha x \\ &= -\alpha^2 \left[\fx \right] \\ &= -\alpha^2 \cdot y \\ \implies\frac{d^2 y}{dx^2} &+ \alpha^2 y = 0 \quad\text{ (answer) } \end{align} %text %
